<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[489, 41, 507, 58]]<|/det|>
## 2  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 74, 128, 91]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 103, 640, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{-2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{-1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 565, 170, 582]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 598, 324, 616]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 650, 252, 667]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 682, 154, 698]]<|/det|>
upthrust  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 723, 341, 741]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 763, 208, 780]]<|/det|>
electric current  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 795, 230, 811]]<|/det|>
resistors in series  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 828, 240, 845]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 96, 640, 528]]<|/det|>
\[g = 9.81 \mathrm{m s}^{-2}\] \[c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\] \[e = 1.60 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\] \[1 \mathrm{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{kg}\] \[m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{kg}\] \[m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{kg}\] \[N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \mathrm{mol}^{-1}\] \[R = 8.31 \mathrm{J K}^{-1} \mathrm{mol}^{-1}\] \[k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{J K}^{-1}\] \[G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{N m}^{2} \mathrm{kg}^{-2}\] \[\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{F m}^{-1}\] \[\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{m F}^{-1})\] \[h = 6.63 \times 10^{-34} \mathrm{J s}\] \[\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{W m}^{-2} \mathrm{K}^{-4}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 598, 583, 636]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 650, 551, 668]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 680, 544, 698]]<|/det|>
\[F = \rho gV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 712, 555, 747]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{V\pm V_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 761, 554, 780]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 792, 608, 812]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 821, 615, 855]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 72, 332, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 72, 332, 89]]<|/det|>
Define pressure.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 133, 870, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 163, 181, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 863, 183]]<|/det|>
Use the answer to (a)(i) to show that the SI base units of pressure are \(\mathsf{kg} \mathsf{m}^{-1} \mathsf{s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 273, 920, 292]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 146, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
A horizontal pipe has length \(L\) and a circular cross-section of radius \(R\). A liquid of density \(\rho\) flows through the pipe. The mass \(m\) of liquid flowing through the pipe in time \(t\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 345, 584, 381]]<|/det|>
\[m = \frac{\pi(\rho_2 - \rho_1)R^4\rho t}{8kL}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 388, 794, 407]]<|/det|>
where \(p_1\) and \(p_2\) are the pressures at the ends of the pipe and \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 419, 432, 437]]<|/det|>
Determine the SI base units of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 655, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 686, 146, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 686, 920, 720]]<|/det|>
An experiment is performed to determine the value of \(k\) by measuring the values of the other quantities in the equation in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 732, 698, 750]]<|/det|>
The values of \(L\) and \(R\) each have a percentage uncertainty of \(2\%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 763, 920, 797]]<|/det|>
State and explain, quantitatively, which of these two quantities contributes more to the percentage uncertainty in the calculated value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 881, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 903, 920, 922]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 621, 90]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by the centre of gravity of an object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Two blocks are on a horizontal beam that is pivoted at its centre of gravity, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 203, 871, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 392, 591, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 424, 920, 473]]<|/det|>
A large block of weight \(54 \text{N}\) is a distance of \(0.45 \text{m}\) from the pivot. A small block of weight \(2.4 \text{N}\) is a distance of \(0.95 \text{m}\) from the pivot and a distance of \(0.35 \text{m}\) from the right-hand end of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 485, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
The right-hand end of the beam is connected to the ground by a string that is at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The beam is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 533, 181, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 533, 784, 552]]<|/det|>
By taking moments about the pivot, calculate the tension \(T\) in the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 715, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... N [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 747, 181, 766]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 747, 692, 766]]<|/det|>
The string is cut so that the beam is no longer in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 778, 920, 812]]<|/det|>
Calculate the magnitude of the resultant moment about the pivot acting on the beam immediately after the string is cut.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 888, 920, 907]]<|/det|>
<form>resultant moment = ................................................. Nm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The beam in **(b)** rotates when the string is cut and the small block of weight \(2.4 \text{N}\) is projected through the air. Fig. 2.2 shows the last part of the path of the block before it hits the ground at point Y.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 125, 757, 272]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 284, 591, 303]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 314, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
At point X on the path, the block has a speed of \(3.4 \text{m s}^{-1}\) and is at a height of \(1.8 \text{m}\) above the horizontal ground. Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 183, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 361, 920, 394]]<|/det|>
Calculate the decrease in the gravitational potential energy of the block for its movement from X to Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 514, 920, 534]]<|/det|>
decrease in gravitational potential energy = ............................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 547, 181, 565]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 546, 920, 580]]<|/det|>
Use your answer to **(c)(i)** and conservation of energy to determine the kinetic energy of the block at Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 781, 920, 800]]<|/det|>
<form>kinetic energy = .................................................... J [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 812, 181, 831]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 812, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
State the variation, if any, in the direction of the acceleration of the block as it moves from X to Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 858, 920, 877]]<|/det|>
<form>............................................................................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 747, 91]]<|/det|>
The block passes point X at time \(t_{\mathrm{x}}\) and arrives at point Y at time \(t_{\mathrm{y}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.3, sketch a graph to show the variation of the magnitude of the horizontal component of the velocity of the block with time from \(t_{\mathrm{x}}\) to \(t_{\mathrm{y}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 485, 151]]<|/det|>
Numerical values are not required.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 650, 856, 670]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

Describe and explain the motion of the block between time \(t = 3.0 \text{s}\) and time \(t = 6.0 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 225, 178, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 225, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
Force \(X\) produces a total power of \(2.0 \text{W}\) when moving the block between time \(t = 3.0 \text{s}\) and time \(t = 6.0 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 747, 291]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 476, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = .................................................... $m$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 540, 922, 573]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.3, sketch a graph to show the variation of the momentum of the block with time \(t\) from \(t = 0\) to \(t = 6.0 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A spring is suspended from a fixed point at one end. The spring is extended by a vertical force applied to the other end. The variation of the applied force \(F\) with the length \(L\) of the spring is shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 129, 685, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 242, 446]]<|/det|>
For the spring:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 144, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 887, 476]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>

<mark>[Total: 5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A progressive wave travels through a medium. The wave causes a particle of the medium to vibrate along a line P. The energy of the wave propagates along a line Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 606, 136]]<|/det|>
Compare the directions of lines P and Q if the wave is:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 180, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 149, 348, 168]]<|/det|>
a transverse wave

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 210, 181, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 210, 361, 228]]<|/det|>
a longitudinal wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 241, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 146, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
A tube is closed at one end. A loudspeaker is placed near the other end of the tube, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 312, 771, 428]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 444, 591, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
The loudspeaker emits sound of frequency \(1.7 \text{kHz}\). The speed of sound in the air in the tube is \(340 \text{m s}^{-1}\). A stationary wave is formed with an antinode A at the open end of the tube. There is only one other antinode A inside the tube, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 537, 250, 555]]<|/det|>
Determine:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 570, 180, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 570, 430, 588]]<|/det|>
the wavelength of the sound

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 707, 920, 726]]<|/det|>
<form>wavelength = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 739, 181, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 739, 388, 757]]<|/det|>
the length \(L\) of the tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 831, 920, 850]]<|/det|>
<form>L = .................................................... m [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
the maximum wavelength of the sound from the loudspeaker that can produce a stationary wave in the tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 195, 920, 213]]<|/det|>
<form>maximum wavelength = .................................................... $m$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[916, 196, 920, 214]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 144, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
Two polarising filters are arranged so that their planes are vertical and parallel. The first filter has its transmission axis at an angle of \(35^{\circ}\) to the vertical and the second filter has its transmission axis at angle \(\alpha\) to the vertical, as shown in Fig. 5.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 282, 907, 426]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 443, 534, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
Angle \(\alpha\) is greater than \(35^{\circ}\) and less than \(90^{\circ}\). A beam of vertically polarised light of intensity \(8.5 \text{W} \text{m}^{-2}\) is incident normally on the first filter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 181, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 521, 811, 539]]<|/det|>
Show that the intensity of the light transmitted by the first filter is \(5.7 \text{W} \text{m}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 613, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 643, 183, 661]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 643, 759, 661]]<|/det|>
The intensity of the light transmitted by the second filter is \(5.2 \text{W} \text{m}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 675, 348, 692]]<|/det|>
Calculate angle \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 831, 892, 850]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\alpha =\) .................................................... \(^\circ\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 833, 920, 850]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 863, 920, 881]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 500, 90]]<|/det|>
The current in a filament lamp decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 640, 121]]<|/det|>
State and explain how the resistance of the lamp changes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[860, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 196, 146, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
A cylindrical wire has length \(L\) and resistance \(R\). The total number of free electrons (charge carriers) contained in the volume of the wire is \(N\). Each free electron has charge \(e\). The potential difference between the ends of the wire is \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 836, 275]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions, in terms of some or all of the symbols \(e, L, N, R\) and \(V\) for:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 183, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 376, 306]]<|/det|>
the current in the wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<form>current = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 428, 181, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 428, 556, 446]]<|/det|>
the average drift speed of the free electrons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 662, 920, 681]]<|/det|>
<form>average drift speed = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 694, 181, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 694, 870, 712]]<|/det|>
the average time taken for a free electron to move along the full length of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 817, 920, 835]]<|/det|>
<form>time taken = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 848, 920, 866]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(9.0 \text{V}\) and negligible internal resistance is connected to a light-dependent resistor (LDR) and a fixed resistor, as shown in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 112, 675, 259]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 274, 532, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 813, 324]]<|/det|>
The LDR and fixed resistor have resistances of \(1800 \Omega\) and \(1200 \Omega\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 566, 355]]<|/det|>
Calculate the potential difference across the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 476, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<form>potential difference = .................................................... V [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 507, 146, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 507, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
The circuit in (a) is now modified by adding a uniform resistance wire XY and a galvanometer, as shown in Fig. 7.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 549, 697, 765]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 781, 591, 800]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 812, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
The length of the wire XY is \(1.2 \text{m}\). The movable connection Z is positioned on the wire XY so that the galvanometer reading is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 606, 88]]<|/det|>
Calculate the length XZ along the resistance wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[484, 244, 920, 263]]<|/det|>
<form>length XZ = ....................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 275, 180, 294]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 275, 920, 308]]<|/det|>
The environmental conditions change causing a decrease in the resistance of the LDR. The temperature of the LDR remains constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 322, 695, 339]]<|/det|>
State whether there is a decrease, increase or no change to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 352, 598, 371]]<|/det|>
· the intensity of the light illuminating the LDR

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 414, 556, 432]]<|/det|>
· the total power produced by the battery

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 476, 653, 494]]<|/det|>
· the length XZ so that the galvanometer reads zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 523, 920, 542]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 553, 922, 572]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 653, 91]]<|/det|>
Nucleus P and nucleus Q are isotopes of the same element.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 685, 121]]<|/det|>
Nucleus Q is unstable and emits a \(\beta^{- }\) particle to form nucleus R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 183, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 440, 153]]<|/det|>
For nuclei P and Q, compare:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 165, 420, 183]]<|/det|>
· the number of protons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 227, 433, 244]]<|/det|>
· the number of neutrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 303, 181, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
When nucleus Q decays to form nucleus R, the quark composition of a nucleon changes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 670, 352]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 364, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 444, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
<form>............................................................................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 146, 494]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 660, 920, 678]]<|/det|>
